Meaning: lacking
Usage: She did not think her vocabulary was wanting, yet there were so many words that inevitable she found a few she didn’t know.

Meaning: still in existence (usually refers to documents)
Usage: Despite many bookstores closing, experts predict that some form of book dealing will still be extant generations from now.

Meaning: to speak in an evasive way
Usage: The cynic quipped, “There is not much variance in politicians; they all seem to prevaricate”.
hindi/gujarati: સાચી હકીકત છુપાવવા ઉડાઉ જવાબ આપવો

Meaning: to reproach, to scold
Usage: Bob took a risk walking into the “Students Barbershop” - in the end he had to upbraid the apparently drunk barber for giving him an uneven bowl cut.

Meaning: narrowly restricted in scope or outlook
Usage: Jasmine was sad to admit it, but her fledgling relationship with Jacob did not work out because his culinary taster were simply too parochial; “After all,” she quipped on her blog, “he considered Chef Boyardee ethnic food.”

Meaning: to reveal or make known something usually unintentionally
Usage: With the gold medal at stake, the gymnast awaited his turn, his quivering lip betraying his intense emotion.

Meaning: being disrespectful; improperly forward or bold
Usage: Dexter, distraught over losing his pet dachshund, Madeline, found the police officer’s questions impertinent- after all, he thought, did she have to pry into such details as to what Madeline’s favorite snack was?

Meaning: to assert
Usage: The scientists maintained that the extinction of dinosaurs was most likely brought about by a drastic change in climate.

Meaning: making less guilty or more forgivable
Usage: The jury was hardly moved by the man’s plea that his loneliness was an extenuating factor in his crime of dognapping a prized pooch.

Meaning: describes someone who is brilliant and lively
Usage: Richard Feyman was renowned for his scintillating lectures- the arcana of quantum physics was made lucid as he wrote animatedly on the chalkboard.

Meaning: to be remorseful
Usage: Though he stole his little sister’s licorice stick with malevolent glee, Chucky soon became contrite when his sister wouldn’t stop crying.

Meaning: to deceive
Usage: Many people have been fleeced by Internet scams and never received their money back.

Meaning: an ill-tempered or violent woman
Usage: Poor Billy was the victim of the virago’s invective-she railed at him for a good 30-minutes about how he is the scum of the earth for speaking loudly on his cellphone in.

Meaning: emaciated; gaunt
Usage: Some actors take challenging roles in which they have to lose so much weight that the appear cadaverous.

Meaning: to search for something persistently
Usage: Ever the resourceful lexicographer, Fenton was able to ferret out the word origin of highly obscure word.

Meaning: open and honest
Usage: The mayor, despite his avuncular face plastered about the city, was hardly aboveboard - some concluded that it was his ingratiating smile that allowed him to engage in corrupt behavior and get away with it.

Meaning: the power to foresee the future
Usage: Baxter’s warnings about investing in technology stocks seemed like an act of prescience after the whole market declined segnificantly.

Meaning:
an excessive supply (n)
supply with an excess of (v)
Usage:
The Internet offers such a glut of news related stories that many find it difficult to know which story to read first.
In the middle of economic crises, hiring managers find their inboxes glutted with resumes.

Meaning: characterized by unusual lightness and delicacy
Usage: The gossamer wings of a butterfly, which allow it to fly, are also a curse, so delicate they are often damaged.

Meaning: to chuckle, laugh merrily, often in a breathy, muffled way
Usage: Walking into the cafe, I could hear happy, chortling people and smell the rich aroma of roasted coffee beans.

Meaning:
serving no useful purpose
more than is needed, desired, or required
Usage:
How can we hope to stay open if we don’t eliminate all superfluous spending, like catered meetings and free acupuncture Tuesday?
The third paragraph in your essay is superfluous and can be deleted.

Meaning: a state of guilt
Usage: Since John had left his banana peel at the top of the stairwell, he accepted culpability for Martha’s broken leg.

Meaning: an act of deliberate betrayal; a breach of trust
Usage: Sure, he was the best salesman in the company; but Michael had abused the trust of the firm, sharing product secrets with a competitor, and for such perfidy he was terminated.

Meaning: a strong liking
Usage: Monte had a predilection for the fine things in life: Cuban cigars, 200 dollars bottles of wine, and trips to the French Riviera.

Meaning: overly sentimental to the point that it is disgusting, Maudlin
Usage: The film was incredibly mawkish, introducing highly likeable characters only to have them succumb to a devastating illness by the end of the movies.

Meaning:
the trait of being rude and impertinent
the feeling of deep and bitter anger and ill will
Usage:
The speeding car had the gall to switch five lanes at once, run through a red light, and then cut off a police car before finally coming to a stop in from of the sea of flashing red lights.
In an act of gall, Leah sent compromising photos of her ex-boyfriend to all his co-workers and professional contacts.

Meaning: Conspicuously and offensively loud, given to vehement outcry
Usage: In giving Marcia a particular vociferous response, Paul caused people at every other table in the restaurant to turn around and look at them angrily.

Meaning:
contain or include
consider (an instance of something) as part of a general rule or principle
Usage:
The rogue wave quickly subsumed the pier and boardwalk, destroying everything in it’s path.
Don Quixote of La Mancha subsumes all other modern novels, demonstrating modern literary devices and predating even the idea of a postmodern, metanarrative.

Meaning: not inclined towards physical exertion or effort; slow and relaxed
Usage: As the sun beat down and temperature climbed higher, we spent a languid week lying around the house.

Meaning: plausible but false
Usage: When listening to a politician speak, it is hard to distinguish the spurious claims from the authentic ones.

Meaning: a person who holds unorthodox opinions in any field (not merely religion)
Usage: Though everybody at the gym told Mikey to do cardio before weights, Mikey was a heretic and always did the reverse.

Meaning: clearly find a way out of one’s duties or obligations
Usage: One way of circumventing the GRE is to apply to a grad school that does not require GRE scores.

Meaning: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as unworthy
Usage: The haughty manager did not believe that any of his subordinates could ever have an insight as brilliant as his.

Meaning: free of deceit
Usage: At first I thought my niece was guileless, but I then found myself buying her ice cream every time we passed a shop.

Meaning: marked by extreme intensity of emotions or convictions
Usage: While other employees responded to the bad news in a measured way, Andrew responded in a vehement manner, tipping over his desk and shouting at the top of his lungs.

Meaning: found in the ordinary course of events
Usage: Phil gets so involved thinking about Aristotle’s argument that he totally forgets quotidian concerns, such as exercising and eating regularly.

Meaning: discontented as toward authority
Usage: After watching his superior take rations from the soldiers, he quickly became disaffected and rebelled.

Meaning: to pull off a plan or scheme, usually through skill or trickery
Usage: Despite a low GPA, he contrived to get into college, going so far as to write his own glowing letters of recommendation.

Meaning: working in a subtle but destructive way
Usage: Plaque is insidious: we cannot see it, but each day it eats away at our enamel, causing cavities and other dental problems.

Meaning: fanatical patriotism
Usage: North Korea maintains intense control over its population through a combination of jingoism and cult of personality.

Meaning:
a gathering of persons representative of some larger group (n)
dependent on (usually used with upon) (a)
Usage:
A small contingent of those loyal to the king have gathered around the castle to defend it.
Whether the former world champions can win again this year is contingent upon none of its star players getting injured.

Meaning: impervious to correction by punishment
Usage: Tom Sawyer seems like an incorrigible youth until Huck Finn enters the novel; even Sawyer can’t match his fierce individual spirit.

Meaning: serving to warn; expressing reproof or reproach especially as corrective
Usage: At the assembly, the high school vice-principal gave the students an admonitory, warning them of the many risks and dangers of prom night.

Meaning: lacking foresight or imagination
Usage: The company ultimately went out of business because the myopic managers couldn’t predict the changes in their industry.

Meaning: to adopt or support an idea or cause
Usage: As a college student, Charlie espoused Marxism, growing his beard out and railing against the evils of the free-market.

Meaning: the trait of avoiding excesses
Usage: Welles wasn’t known for his temperance-he usually ate enough for two and drank enough for three.

Meaning:
available when required or as promised
at ease in talking to others
Usage:
The President announced that the senators were about to reach a compromise, and that he was eager to read the forthcoming details of the bill.
As a husband, Larry was not forthcoming: if Jill didn’t demand to know details, Larry would never share them with her.

Meaning: easily irritated or annoyed
Usage: Although the three year old was often described as mature for his age, he was petulant and whiny whenever his father forgot to remove the crust from his sandwiches.

Meaning: lacking physical movement skills, especially with the hands
Usage: Within a week of starting, the bumbling new waiter was unceremoniously fired.

Meaning: characteristic of a limited perspective; not fashionable or sophisticated
Usage: Maggie’s enthusiasm about her high school teams seemed provincial to her college classmates, all of whom were following a nationally ranked college team.

Meaning: add details or explanation; clarify the meaning; state in depth
Usage: The CEO refused to expound on the decision to merge our department with another one, and so I quit.

Meaning:
a citizen who is represented in a government by officials for whom he or she votes
an abstract part of something
Usage:
The mayor’s constituents are no longer happy with her performance and plan to vote for another candidate in the upcoming election.
The constituents of the metal alloy are nickel, copper, and tin.

Meaning: dominance over a certain area
Usage: Until the Spanish Armada was defeated in 1587, Spain had hegemony over the seas, controlling waters stretching as far as the Americas.

Meaning: done with very great haste and without due deliberation
Usage: Instead of calling his financial advisor, Harold acted precipitously buying 4,000 shares of the latest “hot” stock, only to find out that the company had history of inflating its year end numbers.

Meaning: charming in a childlike or naive way, cherubic
Usage: She was winsome by nature, and many people were drawn to this free and playful spirit.

Meaning: extremely hungry, devouring or craving food in great quantities
Usage: John didn’t eat much at all during the week he had the flu, so now that he is regaining his health, it’s not surprising that he has a ravenous appetite.

Meaning: In opposite to an established system or institution
Usage: The ruling political party has begun a campaign to shut down subversive websites that it deems as a threat to “national safety”.

Meaning: marked by great carelessness; dependent upon or characterized by chance
Usage: Many golf courses are designed with great care, but the greens on the country golf course seem entirely haphazard.

Meaning: unrestrained by convention or propriety
Usage: Their large donation to the local police department gave the drug cartel the brazen confidence to do their business out in open.

Meaning: reject as untrue or unfounded
Usage: Many in the public believed the rumors of a UFO crash outside town, so the chief of police did everything he could to repudiate the rumors.

Meaning: wasting time
Usage: Lawyers use dilatory tactics so that it takes years before the case is actually decided.

Meaning: compulsory force or threat
Usage: The witness said he signed the contract under duress and argued that the court should cancel the agreement.

Meaning: the feeling or remorse or guilt that comes from doing something bad
Usage: Those who show contrition during their prison terms-especially when under review by a parole board-often get shortened sentences.

Meaning: cause to become widely known
Usage: Before the effects of anesthesia were disseminated, patients had to experience the full pain of a surgery.

Meaning: a state of uncertainty about what should be done (usually following some important event)
Usage: Ever since Elvira resigned as the head of marketing, everything about our sales strategy has been in state of flux.

Meaning: assume as fact
Usage: Initially, Einstein posited a repulsive force to balance Gravity, but then rejected that idea as a blunder

Meaning: confined to and understandable by only an enlightened inner circle
Usage: Map collecting is an esoteric hobby to most, but to geography geeks it is a highly enjoyable pastime.

Meaning: troubled persistently especially with petty annoyance
Usage: With a team of new hires to train, Martha was constantly harried with little questions and could not focus on her projects.
